plist.p: Good afternoon, ladies and gentlemen. Welcome here in rainy London and welcome to the ones watching us per webcast. We will present to you our Q2 fiscal year 2012 numbers and outline to you the assumptions for the outlook for the remaining of this year, for fiscal year 2012.

All documents, the earnings release, the presentation, the flash slide and all other documents are on the Internet, and you can download them as you wish. And the webcast will be replayed also on the Internet, Investor Relation of Siemens.

I would like to refer to the Safe Harbor statement on slide number two of the presentation. And I would like to ask you to please switch off any BlackBerrys, mobile phones you might have. Also, as this is being webcast, I'd ask you to please clearly state your name before asking the question. We will have ample time for Q&A after the speech of both Peter Löscher, Siemens' CEO, and Joe Käser, Siemens' CFO.
And with that, Peter, the word is yours.

Thank you very much, Mariel. Good afternoon also from my side to the second quarter analyst conference. It appears that we are last on a busy day, or you had a very exciting Champions League game and everybody is so exhausted.

Let me summarize the key takeaways. In a nutshell, the performance in the second quarter was mixed, with positive developments particularly regarding revenue growth but also some disappointments in order intake and transmission. We have been putting a lot of emphasis to work on the transmission topics. And I will give you more background in a minute including the implications for the full-year guidance.

The macroeconomic environment remains volatile, but the expected softening of growth rates has only materialized in selective regions like China or parts of Europe, while the U.S. and Germany have held up well.

For Siemens, this resulted in a very robust development of our short-cycle businesses in industry, where we saw particularly strength in the U.S. business. We may see a slight shift of regional growth dynamics during the second half of 2012, but global GDP growth is still expected to be on a moderated level of around 2.8% for the full year.

Overall, our order intake decreased significantly by 16%, mainly due to a much lower number of large orders in Energy and Transportation and Logistics. Due to this fact, our book-to-bill decreased to 0.93, but we see this only as a temporary development. Our backlog remains at a very healthy level of around €100 billion. We accelerated revenue growth to 7% across all sectors, driven by continued backlog conversion in Energy and above-average growth in emerging markets of 10%.

Profitability was substantially burdened by further charges mainly for the German offshore grid connections in Power Transmission. As indicated, the fundamental restructuring of NSN weighted on our equity investments results. This led to a significant decrease of profit from total sectors by 48%. Major part of the difference was also the Areva disposal gain of more than €1.5 billion in the second quarter of last year. Together with the additional NSN effect, this led to a 67% decline in income from continuing operations. We saw some moderate improvement over the last year in our free cash flow, but net working capital stayed on a high level during Q2, and Joe will discuss this topic in more detail.

From a strategic perspective, we continued our selective approach to do bolt-on acquisitions. For example, we strengthened our portfolio in Industrial Software through the acquisition of RuggedCom, a specialized Canadian company providing communications solutions for harsh environments, such as in electric utility substations, oil refineries and rail applications. In Oil & Gas, we complemented our subsea power grid offering by taking over the Connectors and Measurement division of Expro Holdings.

For records, here you just see as an overview of the key figures of the second quarter, which you have already received this morning. The regional perspective for orders and sales in the second quarter provides a mixed picture. The base business in Industry and Healthcare showed solid growth rates but we lacked large orders, particularly in Energy and also in the Rail business. For example, the decline in orders and revenue in China can be explained by missing business for rail equipment in China due to delays in investment decisions.

In Energy, the comparables were particularly tough in Germany where we won three major orders for offshore wind parks a year ago. But also in emerging markets like the Middle East where we booked a major Combined Cycle power plant order in Saudi Arabia in Q2 of last year.

The U.S. showed strength both in orders and revenue in a better-than-anticipated economic environment. Our sales growth was very broad based with particular strength in emerging markets, such as in India with remarkable 48% growth or Brazil achieving 18% increase. For the second quarter, this resulted in a further shift of our revenue distribution towards emerging markets with a share of 31%b up one percentage point over the second quarter of fiscal 2011.

What were the key developments in each of the sectors? First, sector Energy. As already mentioned, orders in Energy went down substantially by 36% due to a broad-based decline of large projects in all divisions. The Energy market remains highly competitive but our sales funnel for the coming quarters looks promising. And we expect a book-to-bill ratio above one for the full year.

Intentionally, we were more selective on orders and walked away from low-margin businesses. The sector's backlog was at a healthy €56 billion at the end of the quarter. A major highlight in Q2 was the order for the 834 megawatt Combined Cycle power plant in Ansan in South Korea where we will deliver, among other equipment, two world-leading H-class turbines to Posco.

Second quarter revenue rose by 10% on the conversion from Energy's strong order backlog with substantial growth in Asia, Australia, and a sharp increase of 42% in the renewal business. I want to point out that besides the challenges in Transmission, the sector Energy delivered a very solid quarter regarding profit and once again proved that our position as the only integrated energy company is fully intact.

Fossil delivered 17.5% profit margin and continued its excellent project execution in the solution business, also achieved a strong earnings contribution from the service business. We were very pleased to see Renewable Energy rebounding from the weak Q1 and also taking up profitability sharply to 8.2%, which was basically volume and top-line-driven.

Our clear number one position in Offshore Wind gives us a competitive advantage since we achieved a healthy revenue mix of around one-third of Offshore and two-thirds on Onshore businesses in the first half of fiscal 2012. We are working hard to maintain the lead in Offshore Wind and stay competitive in Onshore to be successful in the expected difficult market conditions ahead. Besides ongoing pricing pressure and expected industry consolidation, this is mainly caused by the uncertainty over the extension of the U.S. tax benefit scheme beyond 2012.

Power Transmission reported a significant loss of €169 million in the second quarter, major factors were additional charges of €278 million we had to take, mostly related to the grid connections to Offshore Wind farm projects in Germany.

Let me give you give you some background about the situation in Power Transmission. I will touch on the project challenges in Germany as well as how we address the structural margin erosion the entire industry faces in important parts of this business.

During the second quarter, we conducted a very detailed and thorough review of all of our offshore grid connection projects in the North Sea. As a consequence, we had to rework our installation schedule for BorWin2 and HelWin1 platform, whose installation dates are anticipated to be delayed to 2013.

We will apply the experience gained from the initial projects to improve and accelerate the installation processes of the following two platforms but anticipate also a delay for the SylWin1 platform. And we are working very closely together with our customer, TenneT, to ensure that the commissioning dates are delayed as little as possible. Main reasons for this unsatisfactory development are: firstly, that we underestimated the execution challenges and the complexity of these projects.

I don't want to sound like providing an excuse, but this kind of offshore grid installations have not been done before. An 800-megawatt platform has a weight of up to 19,000 tons in around 70 meters water depth and 100 kilometers off the coast. The timeslot for installation work is restricted to the period from May to September because of weather conditions. And for all this – those reasons, it's also much more complex compared to existing AC offshore platforms we have successfully installed already in the U.K.

Secondly, the required authorization and documentation processes turned out to be more complex since they are in part unclear and not yet harmonized. And thirdly it became clear that our resources have not been sufficient to execute multiple projects in a very time – timely time schedule.

For mainly these reasons, we booked additional charges of €78 million at Transmission in the second quarter to cover for the expected extension of project durations. The additional resources and requirement and required material and liquidated damages as consortium leader.

It is fair to say that we now have a better understanding of the situation and have put a lot of effort into measures to mitigate and to contain the risks. One example is the set-up of a joint working groups with the authorities, with the grid operators and our peers to work on the standardization of the regulatory environment and the approval processes. In addition, we have massively ramped up our resources in the offshore grid competence center in Hamburg. We feel we get this major mistake step-by-step under control and can learn from these experiences for future tenders and future projects.

Are we completely through with charges on these topics? I cannot rule out entirely that we will see some more impact in coming quarters, but this certainly should be more limited. One thing is clear; HVDC is a very promising technology and a very promising growth market for us where we expect globally around 250 gigawatts of new installations in the current decade. For comparison, the globally installed base has been 100 gigawatts so far.

In particular, in Europe, there will be a number of further tenders of offshore wind grid connections and other HVDC projects similar to the recently awarded Western Link between England and Scotland. We want our fair share in this attractive market but with a clear focus on risk control and profitability. If a project does not meet these standards, we will have the discipline to walk away.

Now, I want to come back to the structural challenges in parts of the Transmission business. As we all know, the margins in the transmission market have suffered across the industry in recent quarters, particularly the high voltage substations and transformers area due to aggressive Asian competition from China and Korea. Furthermore, there are significant overcapacities, particularly in the transformers area. And for these reasons, we have taken initial steps to improve competitiveness in Transmission.

First, as a clear sign of accountability, we decided to change the leadership of the division. Yesterday, we announced that Karlheinz Springer will take over the divisional CEO role with immediate effect. He is a very experienced manager who was previously responsible for the excellent development of Instrumentation & Electrical business unit in the Fossil division. He has experience in project management and project execution and will be of great help in this regard.

Second, Transmissions, the organization, we changed it. We streamlined it from four business units into three. We have created two product business units, clearly focusing around substations and transformers. And then we have combined a third one into the solution division. So, there will be a combined effort across different product areas in this division really focusing on the solutions. And therefore, we have also bundled all the relevant project management.

And third, the new leadership team will work out a comprehensive structure concept to sustainably improve competitiveness in the months to come. So, Karlheinz has, I think, the opportunity within the next 100 days, together with his new team to work closely and to identify for us exactly which type of measures has to be taken, what should be done and how do we move forward.

Let me move on Healthcare. Healthcare delivered a strong operational performance and was diligently executing on Agenda 2013 to improve competitiveness and drive innovation. Order growth was 1%, mainly driven from double-digit growth in Asia, Australia while the Americas were below last year due to some weakness in equipment orders in U.S.

Revenue growth improved to 5%, with China showing, again, substantial double-digit increases also, and also strength in Americas. Healthcare's well on-track to execute the Agenda 2013 as outlined during the recent Capital Market Day. We recorded charges of €38 million to reposition radiation therapy and improve the cost position of Diagnostics. And we expect further charges for the program in coming quarters amounting to around €200 million in total for the fiscal 2012, as guided during the Capital Market Day.

We continue to launch new competitive mid-range product innovations, so-called SMART products. And a few weeks ago, we launched the MAGNETOM Spectra, a 3-Tesla-MR system for broad-based clinical use. And it's another product where we fully leverage our globally optimized R&D and manufacturing set-up while product ownership lies in China.

Diagnostics contributed to the overall Healthcare performance with 3% revenue growth, driven also by strength in Asia. As expected, the underlying margins saw a decline due to a less favorable business mix. And I think this was also already explained during the Healthcare Capital Market Day. Industry showed a very strong performance in a robust business environment. Revenue in the sector was up 8% year-over-year, while orders went down slightly by 1% due to a soft development in Asia. Main revenue driver was a strong increase in the U.S. and healthy growth in Europe, particularly driven by the export-driven German machine builders benefiting the motion control business and the strong automotive industry.

Profitability in Industry Automation improved 20 basis points due to revenue growth related margin drop, through which overcompensated for increased selling expenses and footprint expansion. Industry Automation continues to strengthen its software business and has launched, besides the already closed RuggedCom acquisition, a successful takeover bid for German quality management software company, IBS. As indicated in Q1, Drive Technology returned to double-digit profitability with 11.5% due to the successful OpEx management over the last quarter.

And finally, I want to briefly highlight the key developments in the sector Infrastructure & Cities. Order volume for the sector declined by 8% due to fewer large rolling stock orders. Nevertheless, Rail Systems was again able to win a contract for 20 Desiro regional trains in the U.K. for the customer London Midland for around €170 million.

Profit in Transportation & Logistics division achieved 5.3%, 110 basis points below the prior year level, due to lower revenue and some impact from lower margins in long-term contracts. The Power Grid Solutions & Products division saw a nice improvement in profitability to 6.1%, due to improved revenue growth and drop-through in the low- and medium-voltage business.
Building Technologies profit margin decreased slightly to 5.3% despite revenue growth of 7%, driven by strong U.S. business. It was held back partially by higher expenses for growth initiatives.

After six months into the fiscal year, I want to briefly update you also on the performance in our One Siemens operational framework. Our growth rate of 4.5% is 4.7 percentage points below the 9.2% reported by our peers. And one reason and the major reason is obviously that we have clearly more focus on organic growth versus the acquisition effects by our major competitors. But also on the organic side, we are slightly growing slower than our competitors.

Over the last quarters, we have taken significant investments in growth, be it sales force or additional research and development. And it's our goal to reap the benefits from these investments in the quarters to come and, at the same time, limit the OpEx increase for the second half of 2012. And also going into 2013, there is a clear focus on productivity, cost control and ensuring that we have set the base for our future growth initiatives and reaping the benefits of it going into the rest of the year and into 2013.

After six months, Industry and Healthcare are well within the targeted EBITDA ranges, while Infrastructure & Cities is catching up with a lower – from the lower target range, and Energy is also just shy from the range at 9%, strongly impacted by the Transmission challenges which I've just highlighted. Despite the abovementioned headwinds, we still delivered on our ambition of capital efficiency by achieving return of capital employed of 16.4%. Our capital structure ratio is – with 0.3, still below our target of 0.5 to 1 for adjusted net debt over EBITDA, although the dividend payment in Q1 and the weaker cash flow development during the first six months brought us closer to the target range.
And with that, let me now turn over to Joe.

Thank you very much, Peter. Hi, everyone. Very warm welcome also from my side. What I will do now in the next three or four slides is to take you through our cash flow development and move on to the debt, for which I'll give some input on top line gross margin pricing and OpEx development. And then, obviously, finally, last but not least, try to shed some light into the so-called below-the-line items of our company's P&L.

If we take a look on the free cash flow development, you should see here as a green line, then I guess there are a couple of things I want to mention. First of all, in the first six months, we have significantly increased our inventories by €1.5 billion, and also accounts receivables by almost €600 million in order also to reflect the continued revenue growth and expected growth also in revenues for the second half. And there has been a material decline on the prepayments including the biddings in excess, and that amounts to €700 million for the first half of fiscal 2012. And the ones who have been following us for a longer period of time already know and remember that it's been consistently mentioned in that item that there is some behavioral change if it comes to bigger, or especially from the public sector as far as prepayments are concerned.

Now, obviously looking into the second half of the year, what one could expect from free cash flow is that we assume that we will follow the trend as the second half usually is stronger than the first half. And if, I guess, we assume to move along the purple line of the free cash flow developments, I would expect that to be shy of the purple line for 2012.

Again, we have delivered very, very strong fee cash flow in 2010 and 2011 when bookings have been growing and so obviously did prepayments at that time. Now, those projects are being called to notice and we need to ramp up our working capital in order to also fulfill and make good on those projects.

Now, obviously, this has a cumulative catch-up. So, over time, that will normalize. But for 2012, and likely the first half of 2013, we continue to expect a somewhat weak free cash flow due to that development. In general, as far as cash outflow is concerned, please also remember that we still expect some cash outflow from accruals taken during the course of the SIS transaction which we reserved for in 2011.

Now, if we look at the net debt bridge, obviously, net debt has increased from €8 billion total net debt in Q1 to €10.6 billion. If you look into the mostly operating activities, you can see that the income development and improvement obviously has contributed by €2.4 billion. And the increase in inventories, as mentioned, but also with the dividend have contributed to the increase in net debt. We do expect net debt to, without any major other topics such as M&A and the like, to be brought back to levels which we have seen in Q1.

Now that shortly for this one, let me now spend some more time on the topic of what we expect in the top-line, in pricing, and the like going forward. If we look at the chart, which you might remember from our last presentation in November 2011, when we talked about what we expect for 2012 going forward, as far as customer price change is concerned within the P&L environment and in the revenues, we kind of expect a level between 2.6%, 2.8% on average. So that comes in as expected in the P&L on the revenues.

So, the pressure, what we have been seeing quite for a long time, is more on the booking side. And that one predominantly in large projects or infrastructure and power such as substations, as well as in commodity like of products, but first and foremost, in the environment of distribution transformers. And that definitely has become a commodity, latest due to the fact that a lot of Chinese players have used the so-called financial and economic crisis to boost their strengths in 2009 and 2010, and you see that now to come to market.

Now, on the gross margin for 2012, in the first half, you've seen that's been having a gross margin of 28.6%, and obviously, also negatively affected by the fact that we had to book those charges in Transmission, due to cost of goods sold. For the second half, one can expect some ease of gross margins will be stable, maybe a few ticks up mostly in Energy, in parts also in Industry, and we expect Healthcare and IC, Infrastructures & Cities, to just be about flat as far as gross margin is concerned. So, we do continue to offset the pricing pressure in the revenue environment by productivity and innovation in our factories and to go to – and the logistics all along. So, as far as the underlying gross margin is concerned, we do expect, as I've said, to maintain the levels in the second half of fiscal year.

Revenues will obviously also grow over the first half of our fiscal year, half year-over-half year, but obviously, we do expect that growth dynamics if we compare first half and second half of the year to slow down in the year-over-year comparison.

In the OpEx environment, Peter has mentioned that already. We've invested a lot of resources into the go-to-market to strengthen our regional footprint, as well as engineering for second-wave emerging markets. It's been €1.2 billion in 2011. It's been a significant amount of money now in 2012, in the first half. And we expect now that investment to deliver in the second half but predominantly also in 2013. So, what the market can expect is that there will be some OpEx increase in 2012, which is just about below the corridor of €1.1 billion to €1.3 billion. And that's what we are targeting for 2012. We also will make sure that there is quite a focus on OpEx as far as productivity is concerned during the budget season for 2013.

On the CapEx, you can also see that it's been investing about €2 billion in – or expected to be invest about €2 billion. We'll maintain that level, and that level will be on the lower end of the corridor. Maybe just a bit high of the €1.9 billion which we have been setting as a lower target for CapEx.

Now, that brings me to the item on – below the sectors. If we take a look on our fiscal Q2 below the sector line, you can see a few matters, obviously, the huge charge we have been taking on our NSN equity investment. NSN had – besides some weakness in the operational environment, also took significant restructuring charges of about €770 million, about €500 million of that being Germany. So, the good news on that is NSN was able to finish the negotiations quicker on the agreement with the union in Germany as originally anticipated. So, that should save some time to apply to focusing of the market.

And at the customer environment, there was a write-off of about €190 million on tax assets and some PPA and financial expenses which all add up to more than €1.2 billion in total. And obviously Siemens gets just about half of it. Are we satisfied with that, obviously, that's a rhetorical question, and we made it increasingly clear that the company now needs to step up and deliver on its restructuring and refocusing on the market. You might have heard that NSN is now going after broadband mobility and they will focus on that one rather than all the methods which are possible in the telecommunications environment.

SFS has delivered a decent income, €74 million, a bit shy of what it had in Q1. We've seen some smaller credit hits, mostly in the U.S. No reason to be concerned; and we do expect the SFS to maintain its strengths on operating performance. The so-called centrally managed portfolio assets are mostly sold. There are – some remain this year, and we do not expect any major volatility going forward.

The second extraordinary item, above and beyond the NSN charges obviously has been the corporate items and pensions with a positive €105 million. If I add everything up, it has been some sort of positive one-off. I could easily add up a total of about €150 million which contributed positively as one-offs in that environment. Obviously €95 million legal and regulatory matters, a positive on our asset retirement obligation, which we have for a very long time. This obviously also is depending on the development of discount rates and the like, so very difficult to manage; this time it was positive. And there have been a few other positive impacts which cannot be expected as an underlying contribution going forward.

Corporate treasury, same matter. Obviously, this is about interest hedging overlays on currencies and the like, which do not qualify for hedge accounting. So, there's a quite some volatility there. Tax obviously being in terms of tax bracket, it's rather high because of the NSN losses could not be deducted. We do expect the tax rate to be in the 28%, 30% range going forward, so that should be a safe place to add to the model.

SRE has been also at zero due to the lack of disposals. We continue to dispose of items which are not needed in the company. However, obviously, we also need to look into the market environment as it develops going forward.

Now, if we look what to expect in the second half of the fiscal year, obviously on NSN, we do expect some more repositioning charges, but obviously the maturity has been done in Q2. There's been a few more areas outside Germany which still need to be agreed upon with the union. The maturity, as I said, obviously has been done. Bosch appliances will be somewhat flattish, so one could expect a significant ease as compared to the first half, but still NSN, different market remains to be volatile over time.

As far as the savings of NSN are concerned, they will kick in at a very late stage of calendar year 2012. So, it could easily be that we, in our fiscal year, which obviously ends in September 30th, will be some of that early returns. So, they should actually be coming by the end of the calendar year 2012 and positively affecting the NSN cost structure as we move along.

On SFS and CMPA, should pretty much be actually in line with fiscal 2011. So, I would not expect any major deviations on those two items as compared to 2011. SFS might be a bit up, maybe the CMPA a bit down. But all in all, that should be a good ballpark to assume.

SRE, obviously dependent on the disposal of real estate. We should see some gains mostly in Q4. So, if someone puts some €80 million, €100 million into that bucket, that should be a decent way of looking at it. The most volatile topic, obviously, are the pensions and the asset retirement applications because that could go both ways.

So, for the remainder of 2012 second half of our fiscal year, if someone puts about a €200 million on average into each quarter, it should be on the pretty safe side. Q3 obviously being a bit less in costs, and Q4 to the year-end usually is a bit higher. So, €200 million each quarter for the remainder of fiscal should actually play it pretty safe. As far as this is concerned, corporate treasury, again, if someone puts in a €50 million expected run rate on cost for interest hedging overlays, depending how the currency goes, should also be a decent way to cover for that item.
So, that pretty much, ladies and gentlemen, covers what I thought I give the market in terms of disclosure on those items. And I hand it back to Peter for the final remarks.

Thank you, Joe. Let me finish off with the revised guidance for this year. We confirm the moderate growth in revenue. Also, in terms of order intake being above one in relation to turnovers to a positive book-to-bill. We continue to anticipate strong earnings performances in most of our businesses, including the industrial short cycle businesses. And last but not least, in November 2011, if you remember, at the height of the European crisis, we set out an ambitious, but at that time realistic, target of €6 billion for our income from continuing operations. And due to the challenges mostly in our Power Transmission business, the level we have – we are reducing this number by €600 million to €800 million.
So, with this, Joe and myself are happy to take your questions.
So, we'll start the Q&A right in the middle of this room. If you can have Frederic Stahl, please.

Good afternoon, gentlemen. It's Frederic at UBS. I have two questions on Transmission. Is there a positive – given what's happened in the business in the last two quarters, is there a positive impact on how you run other project-related businesses across Siemens? Is there a reason for you to review the operations elsewhere because of what's happened in Transmission?

The second question is I've understood from some of your customers that there's a trend now from among buyers and grid operators to split up or separate the tendering process. For example, you would have a tender for the substations, you would have a tender for the cables rather than just have one large tender for the whole package. Is that correct and is that – well, is that something that you're seeing in your markets right now?

Yeah. Let me make one thing very clear. I mean, this is – if you remember, first of all, Siemens has not project issues across the board because obviously one concern could be – is Siemens now having not learned enough from the – if you remember 2008 when we talked about the fossil power issues. Clearly, when you talk in terms of execution of big projects, we are doing extremely well, and if we take learnings from the Fossil Power division, one of the reasons why this business has actually accelerated in terms of earnings power was not just the mix effect, but also in terms of how it is executing.

So we are doing and we are executing outside this business. Unfortunately, this is a very specific issue which we – quite frankly, we have underestimated the complexity. We should have clearly looked into the issues that this type of technology was never implemented. Even the regulatory authorities are learning along the way, so we're not talking in terms of executing against a very clear cut regulatory environment. We have underestimated that roughly 50% of the value add of this business is actually outside our own competence. So you're really talking about highly complex shipyard type of building in terms of platform building. And on top of it you have to integrate actually our own business and equipment onto these platforms.

So, the challenge is the integration of it. And therefore we have made all the assessments and it's a combination of picking the right partners. It's a combination how you share risks among the partners, and then ensuring that from a competency profile we ensure that we are successfully implementing these projects. So, this is a highly specific issues which we're addressing.

And quite frankly, in hindsight, but if I share with you the learnings, one of the learnings is we should have taken one project. Unfortunately, the first one was won by ABB, then we have won four in a row in a very, very short timeframe basically in the window of 12 months. And then the last one was again won by ABB.

So, in the ideal scenario, we should have taken one, learn from it, taking the best practice, sharing with it, and then move on to the second one. So this was one of the key learnings of it. And we will certainly benefit from it, in terms of the additional projects which will be there in Germany because the first four, when you think about in terms of that at least 16 to 20 of this type of projects coming on the northern shore of Germany in the upcoming years. And we are certainly using this as a very expensive learning experience for the company.

In terms of the issue of splitting it up, we don't see this that this is actually split up in terms of splitting up cables versus substations. We rather see – first of all, there's no blueprint. I mean each customer and each project are different. And having said this there's certainly an issue in terms of joint and several, so you have to very carefully look into contractual issues which you take on, and the liability having Siemens as a partner is in the ideal case for many customers, a more integrated one.

And we have to very carefully assess, and this is what I said earlier, when we bid for such projects, we have to ensure that we perfectly understand the risk reward profile of such projects, carefully assess it, having the right competencies to really assess it carefully, and then make sure where do we bid and where do refrain from bidding. That's the core issue here.
Okay. We'll continue with Andreas Willi and then Peter Reilly.

Yes. Good afternoon. Andreas from JPMorgan. I would like to follow up on transmission more on the underlying business where I'm still a bit puzzled about the margin decline over the years. Given that you were probably the first and most consistent in terms of highlighting the price pressure in this area, why did it take so long then to basically hit the 3% margin before we have this more structural review? And why didn't that come earlier because this was a known issue to the company, given you've always highlighted the problem.

And the second question on pension and IFRS 19, other companies have started highlighting the negative impact from that or impact from that for 2013. Will you implement it in 2013 or 2014? And what's the impact for Siemens mainly on the P&L?

Yeah. Thanks, Andreas. On the rest of transformers, if I may, we definitely have been highlighting the massive pricing issues on substations predominantly. And also continued pricing pressure on commodity transformers back to distribution ones, which face significant competition from China and – I mean that was related to the backlog. As far as the backlog in Q1, someone was asking what are the areas that you are most concerned about and without the knowledge of the platform in the North Sea it was that division. And at some point in time, this margin pressure in the backlog has materialized. Should one have been doing the structural changes earlier, definitely could have done in a way but they are there now. And the division has been quite successful in getting a lot of productivity out of the resources still over the last two, three quarters. But at some point in time, working harder, working more comes to an end. It doesn't incrementally help to bring down the cost and bring up the margin; then you need to go into structural changes, and this is where we are at this time. It's mostly substations and it's distribution transformers where pricing pressure and margin deteriorations have happened in the division.

Pensions, definitely, IFRS 19 will affect the company too, into 2013. On the other hand, obviously, the counterpart is always the expected return on pension assets. So we need to see how we will guide going forward when we come to 2013. But this definitely is a topic, which needs to be addressed at a time.
Okay. We have in the second row Peter Reilly.

Good afternoon. It's Peter Reilly from Deutsche Bank. Peter, 18 months ago, you stood here and told us that Siemens is now a normal company. Since then, you've had the particle therapy. We've had the Areva fine, and now we've got Power Transmission. These are not things I would associate with a normal company. And they're all, in some way, issues of management judgment. Two questions, really. How can you reassure us that there aren't further surprise us in the backlog?
